Here are my reasons:1) Good size venue - You can fit a good amount of people in here to see a smaller size show with a larger concert crowd feel2) Good acoustics - The band on stage sounds very good regardless of where you are in the venue3) Decent sized seats - I have been to some shows where I couldn't stand up because my legs were so cramped because of sitting. The seating obviously needs to be tight but there is a bit more room than many places I have been.4) Intagibles - It just "feels" comfortable. Outside of the somewhat better than average seating. The décor was well done in the hall itself but not overkill ornate. It was a good balance.

31.description: I'm a little late in writing this, but I want to say Taste of Polonia is pure, 100% unaltered Chicago.I've gone several times over years (including this year), even though I have not a single drop of Polish blood in me. However, I always say that if you've lived in Chicago for a certain period of time you'll eventually have Polish friend or two. Or, as in my own case, enough to teach me how to swear, sing "Happy Birthday" and order food in Polish.....This year's Taste was fun. On Saturday I afternoon I went with friends (four of us were 100% Italian and only one was Polish) and we thoroughly enjoyed the Elvis impersonator and the following Polka band. The food was good, and I really liked being able to buy a refillable plastic stein, even though Okocim was not available this year (available was some off-brand European beer that was forgettable). Also, don't forget to stop by the gift stands and get the latest DJ Marski CD, or sign up to win free Chicago Fire tickets.

34.description: Welcome to one of Chicago's greatest streetfests. It is really worth it every year to go hit up Taste of Polonia. One of the greatest outdoor events in the City of Chicago, Taste of Polonia goes on my list of "must sees" and "must do's" before the summer is out. If you like Polish cuisine or anything about Polish culture, you are required by the laws of common sense to strike Taste of Polonia.Taste of Polonia features Polish folk dancing, Okocim, latkes, meatballs, kielbasa, sauertkraut, and all things Polish. The Polish people far outnumber the random Chicago drunks more prevalent at Lincoln Square Mayfest or Oktoberfest so they can handle their liquor much better. Last year I ran into an old man who was completely wasted carrying the largest sack of money I've seen this side of the Pacific Ocean. He also said he had a gun, and 99% of the time someone telling you they have a gun would frighten you, but I laughed hysterically.Every year at Taste of Polonia they set up huge tables so you can sit down, there are places to stand and drink/eat Mayfest-style with giant umbrellas so you don't get sunstroke and they always bring in loads of bands that play great music to go with your Okocim and Polish food.The latkes are where it's at, but I sweat all of the other food too. Calling all foodies: Taste of Polonia is badassery at its finest! One final secret: approach the food booths near the end of the night and start haggling and they will give you triple the food for the price!!!!!!!!

16.description: This venue is so beautiful inside, I was surprised to be going for a rock concert here when there wasn't a "floor" area.   We were seeing Blue Oyster Cult and Foghat!  :- )   LOVED the demographics of the crowd, and the fact that even though there were a lot of folks standing up front, most of the people were sitting and jamming to the classic rock without blocking everyone else's view.  There were a few fans that didn't grow up with these groups acting like they had been given some ecstasy...but other than quite a few people getting angry at the spoilers.....it was a wonderful concert, the acoustics were great, and I would love to go back there again to other performances.   ALSO, Foghat came out and signed autographs which was pretty cool for some of the fans, and the venue made it easy to line everyone up while waiting.

13.description: I only discovered the Copernicus Center recently but I'm quickly realizing it's a great place to be. They offer lots of fun shows (Tributosaurus does the Beatles was amazing) and when they're busy the bar tenders do a great job of keeping up with the flow of the customers. It has a nice concert hall and lots of parking, but do try to get there at least 30 minutes before the show if you can to ensure a decent spot. Check it out if you haven't already!

11.description: I'm part Polish by marriage so I've developed a love of pierogi, kapusta and sausage. We even had to have the DJ play a couple of polkas at our wedding reception. Since these types of things aren't every day occurrences, when there's a chance for Polish food/Polish music, we're there. Taste of Polonia is a great fest. It winds around outside the Copernicus center which lets them set up the four different entertainment stages. There is traditional Polish music (even not so traditional as we listened to a Polish rapper at one point), a children's entertainment stage, and cover bands. There are also vendor booths--jewelry, toys, and of course Polish-themed items. Got a little one? I love the Polish themed onesies. And the Food--delicious of course. Pierogi, potato pancakes and hunter's stew were my choices for the day and it was all delicious. There were combo plates for the ravenous or polish sausage for a snack. There are tall tables set up under tents where you can lean in and enjoy your meal. I loved the tall tables because our stroller fit nicely underneath, saving space and not causing a tripping hazard in tent aisle. There were also lots of seating near the stages so if you're not up dancing a polka, you can sit and relax, enjoy a brew. This is definitely a family friendly fest; all age ranges represented.

39.description: I saw my friend have his first MMA fight here and I have no complaints.  I don't know if it was the right venue for MMA fighting, but it got the job done.  It would make for a great concert venue.  It is in much better shape than most Chicago venues.  I don't know if they have any shows here that I'd be interested in seeing, but if they did I'd be here in a heartbeat.

37.description: Beautiful space, worthy of yor next event. I wasn't awareof this place and maybe you aren't either so check it out.oh and apparently they have concerts sometimes.

0.description: This review if specifically for the Taste of Polonia. Tonight was my first time getting my T.O.P. cherry popped and it was pretty good. The fest was crowded but family friendly. They charged $7 for admission into the fest. Food, bouncy house, prize games are not included in the fee and run from $5 - $12 each. There were several other games hosted by sponsoring companies that offered opportunities to win little prizes for free (ex. Stickers, pencils, glow sticks, etc). The music was pretty good. There were 3 stages...one had an American band performing top 40 hits, another stage with a Polish rock band, the last stage had a dj. There were several food stands. Make sure you buy your tickets because the vendors do not accept cash. Each ticket is $1, a sheet is $20 (20 tickets). I got the polish platter and for $12, which consists of 3 pierogis, potato pancake,polish sausage, sauerkrate, stuffed cabbage, sour cream, and apple sauce. I enjoyed the char-grilled sausage it was just perfect. The piergoi was pretty good. I felt everything else lacked flavor. My family loved it though, I guess it depends on the person The crowd was majority Polish (duh). There were a handful of different ethnicities, but everyone was there for the same reason, to have fun. I felt comfortable overall. My only complaint was that there were plenty of smokers, which sucks because I'm allergic to cigarette smoke. I guess the ordinance doesn't apply to outdoor fest.Parking is near to impossible. They offered free parking at Hoyne Bank, which was at capacity. The best bet is to find street parking along Jefferson Park. There was additional parking at the lot next to the train station for $12. The center itself had a classical concert. It was filled so I didn't stay, not that I intended to. By the way, this is where the air conditioned bathrooms are located and there was a bar in the lot aka the good liquor.Overall, a great time was had by all and I would recommend visiting this fest at least once. It's a little pricey, but worth it.

38.description: I've been going to Taste of Polonia since I was a little kid and I've never had a bad time.  Plus, Dezerter played a few years ago.  DEZERTER!  Sadly, I missed them, because I found out a week later, but still... legendary Polish hardcore band from the 1980s in Jefferson Park.  I can get behind that.

27.description: I've come here a couple times for a friend's professional MMA events. I'd only known the Copernicus to be for concerts, dance, and art-related occasions, but I was wrong. From the outside, I was pretty skeptical of what the inside would be. To put in lamens terms, it looked sketchy to me. But I was proven wrong once I got inside. The auditorium space is very large and has beautiful structure. A huge balcony are with more seating overlooks the rear. The stage itself is fairly sized. The lobby area is pretty large too, with a bar area to order drinks, and a winding staircase behind it to enter the upper levels of the Copernicus; very nice. The event was great both times (and my friend won his bout both times) so I left with no complaints.

32.description: Never doubt Polish ingenuity.What?  You've never heard of the concept?  Well, you've probably heard that we Poles do things kind of weird (some would even say backwards).  And that might be true.  But what you might not have heard is that to make up for making things more difficult, we come up with innovative solutions to problems we created by doing things the hard way in the first place.Two examples were found this year at Taste of Polonia.1) I griped in last year's review about how tickets are only available in $5 increments.  Well the festival planners heard my cries - sort of.  This year they did something extremely unique.  They made the tickets work like real money (though they could have, you know, just used real money).  Each strip contained three $1 and four $.50 vouchers.  Sure this made things more difficult by now having vendors allowed to price things at $1.50 or $5.50.  But, when the visitor inevitably had to sell their tickets to other patrons (as happens at every festival), it made an exchange easier.  It created a large black market of "independent" ticket sellers.  Just like in Poland under communism.  How authentic!  How ingenious!2) This year the festival adopted the popular concept of refillable mugs.  For $7, you could purchase a plastic mug and have it refilled for $4 all four-day weekend (beers were normally $5).  That is, if you could find someone who spoke enough English to sell you the mug.  When I wandered up to get mine, I asked for the mug three times with increasing volume (and more and more exaggerated hand gestures in mug-like shapes) as the seller looked at me and my cohort blankly and responded with a thickly accented, "mug?"  Finally, one of his co-workers tapped him on the shoulder and whispered something in his ear (probably in Polish).  A look of recognition crossed his face.  He went to the back of the stand and brought back and empty mug and handed me a cup of beer.  Not exactly environmentally conscious (but Poland is an industrial country) but it turned out to reveal a secret.  The savings for the mug refills was minimal because the mug did not hold as much beer as the $5 cup.  How ingenious - of the organizers to pull a fast one on the crowd (it is a great mug though).Still, this festival is the craziest, most fun in the city despite its difficulties.  The oddness of some of the attendees makes this a people-watching zoo!  From aged hippies to polka-dancing old country folks to the creepiest duck mascot ever (PolTel's costumed representative) wandering the crowd scaring small children (and me) the festival is an eye catching treat.Plus the music is incredible.  They dig deep to find cover bands the other festivals won't touch (Libido Funk Circus is a hilarious party anthem band) and bring over Polish stars.  And there's plenty of polka if that floats your boat or rolls your barrel.  There's even a more subdued stage inside the Copernicus Center with choral acts and dance troupes.If they bring back Okocim as a sponsor and official beer and if they keep finding ways to Polish (er polish) it up, next year it might even be better.  Even if they don't, you can't help but admire the inventiveness of Poland in Chicago.

48.description: This is THE place to see a top Polish Pop, Rock or HipHop band.  Minus a star since I'm not a big fan of Polish Pop, Rock or HipHop bands.The rest of the stars are for the big Taste of Polonia fest held here every labor day weekend.  Yummy Polish sausages, kraut, pierogi, Beer and really great people watching too!  I feel completely comfortable here in my dark blue shorts, dark blue dress socks and brown sandals!  Yeah Polish neighbors!

44.description: WOW oh man.........this fest was awesome!  I didnt know what to expect from the Polski fest  when we were heading up there, I just knew I wanted to go because the Polska people are awesome!Of course my liver was on life support from the previous 2 days of punding booze....BUT I had to hit that OKOCIM!!! Nothing like GAmBLING..............Yes I was gambling Out in the open with other polskis!  an we were all drinking Okocim! and of course I have no clue how they do it but they got booze going till 10:45 pm!!! NO OTHER fest in the city does this! hell by 9pm there was a alot of drunk polskis running around! good times ohhh yesssssAnd the GAMBLING! unreal!!!!Polska people you are all awesome!Polski fest will be an annual thing for me!Jin kullaKojam PIVO!!!

24.description: Just  moved into neighborhood - and wanted to give it a try.  $7 dollars in my opinion is a bit HIGH for a neighborhood fest - not knowing what you are going to get for your money.  Also don't advertise the charge as a donation - if MUST pay the fee to enter.

7.description: Great sound and visibility, and some of the most breathtakingly ugly art and interior design on planet Earth. Truly amazing and worth seeing. Wow. The Vatican of kitsch.

49.description: This building was formerly the Gateway Theater many years ago. Now it is used as a cultural center and reception hall in this Polish neighborhood. The tower is an attractive beacon for this area. The annual Taste of Polonia festival is centered around here every Labor Day weekend.

40.description: The Taste of Polonia is officially the Polishest of all Polish fests!It is defintely among the most authentic of the fests, everywhere I turned around people were speaking in Polish. Even the entertainment was bilingual (Polish-English)!  I wished that my Great Grandma had taught me more phrases in Polish :(. The food is wonderful too, just like my Mom made for us growing up.  Pierogis anyone?But that is not the reason for the five star rating.  Taste of Polonia gets five stars simply for the fact that it was the event I had met My Count Gregula in person for the first time five years ago and my life has been changed for the better because of that :).  I love you Greg!

30.description: Chicago is supposedly the largest Polish city other than Warsaw, so it's no surprise that the city has a big Polish celebration.I'm not Polish, so I couldn't entirely appreciate the vendors selling silly t-shirts with kielbasa-related innuendos, but there were a couple nice (amber, ceramic, etc.) jewelry stands.There were a few tribute bands (Beatles, Pink Floyd...) as well as traditional Polish bands performing on the different stages while I was there. They were so loud I could hear them all at once from anywhere in the fest - til I started going deaf. I had to put in my earplugs. Yikes.Unfortunately there weren't really vegan food options. I had some veggie tempura, which was the only thing I could find. (My half-Polish boyfriend explained that Polish people are known for their randomness, like wearing a parka with flip flops or serving Asian food at the Polish fest.) Unfortunately, the tempura was sooo greasy my tummy decided to return it later. :(If you're a sometimes-honey-eating vegan, there was a mead vendor with free samples. Check it out; it's pretty potent though.

46.description: Mmmm, pierogis...The Taste of Polonia is a great festival for everyone - for the Polish and non-Polish (me) alike.  Shhh... don't tell anyone, but when I was 18 I worked for LOT Polish Airlines for about a year.  I didn't learn much Polish, except for the "bad" words, hehe.You'll find great Polish food here (I love Kasia's Deli), and there's plenty of live entertainment to see.  Music, dancing, kielbasa, and Okocim beer.  What more could you ask for?!Their 29th annual festival will be held on Labor Day weekend; from Friday, August 29 thru Monday, September 1st.

1.description: We were going to book our wedding there.  Our dates were open and we explained that to Anna, the person doing the booking.  She gave us a few dates in October and we told her we were looking at one in particular and so the process began of booking both the foyer and the annex for that day.From the January 22nd to February 3rd (a week and a half) we saw the place twice, brought our caterer to see the place, and sent 20 emails back and forth working out the details for the date we chose.On February 3rd she sent the final invoice for us to look over.  She had sent us variations of this invoice several times prior, a new one each time a detail would change. This one was different than all the others though, apart from the price, this one had in big bold letters, ONLY A PAID RENTAL DEPOSIT WILL GUARANTEE YOUR DATE. This was not on any other invoice she sent prior.We replied the next day and asked when we could come sign the contract and give the deposit.  She responded saying that she had bad news.  They booked the theater for the day we were booking our wedding.  Never once did she say someone else was looking at that date, never once did she tell us we needed to put the deposit down ASAP cause we may loose it, not until the final details were ironed out and we were ready to sign were we told we would no longer have that date.  From the beginning we said our dates were flexible.  We were open to covering stained banquet chairs, we were willing to do our ceremony on a Friday, we were open to our caterer having to split his time between two kitchens.  We could have moved our date to a time in November and we have, but at a different venue.

9.description: We were really excited to see this band at Copernicus Center and we purchased tickets 3 months in advance to get front row seating. Everything seemed fine till the band started playing. At that time everybody from the back came up to the stage and blocked us from seeing anything. My child was pushed and jumped on by uncontrolled fans. All exit areas were blocked. During the intermission we went to the security officer with a complaint but he couldn't do anything and admitted that he got yelled at by the management for going on stage and trying to control the crowd from claiming on the stage and throwing beer. We asked for the manager, we were told that her name is Anna and here we got even bigger shocker. She was rude, unpleasant and disrespectful. She had a big group of complaining and concerned people in a front of her and she couldn't care less.  When I told her about the fire hazard and exits being blocked, she laughed and when I told her that in American theater this would never happen, she said that we don't have to come here, that we can go see American shows instead. This was a huge disappointment and believe me, this place lost a lot of clients that day. The band was great but the whole experience was absolutely awful because of neglect and bad management. That's how tradition dies.

26.description: Oh my gosh, this place is gorgeous.  I attended a Multi-Chamber Meeting at the space, not really sure what to expect.  Once inside, I was awed by the winding staircase and the gorgeous bar.  I took a moment away to step into the theatre...I think it may be the most beautiful theatre space I've ever seen.  Simply breathtaking.Would love to see a show there!

25.description: My favorite fest of the year by far. I may be jaded since I am polish but I think this fest is by far one of my favorites. The music is usually pretty good and there are usually lots of options. The food is the real reason to go and the polish combination plates are something that I can't live without. Today I ordered one combo plate devoured it then got a second one to take home for a later meal. The sausage, pierogi, potato pancake, and slaw make the perfect combination. I also enjoy going into the Copernicus center and either watching a cooking demonstration or a polish play. Usually we are going into the center to get cool but this year it was to get out of the wind. They don't have rides but do have carnival games and some stands selling polish items. I will never miss this fest.

12.description: I was super excited when I heard about Taste of Polonia. I had already missed out on one of the other large Polish festivals of the year, so this would have to hold me over until next year. I know you can find a plethora of Polish places in Chicagoland, but there's just something special about going to a venue where you know my people are going to be en mass and shine.We were not fans of the $7pp charge just to walk into the fair. That ended up being $14 that wasn't able to be used toward pierogi. And I'm very unhappy when I don't get my pierogi, especially delicious ones. These ones were fab! The boy and I split a Polish Plate which consisted of potato pancakes, half a Polish sausage, a mix of cheese and meat pierogi, kapusta and a stuffed cabbage. I was very sad when it was gone.The weather was quite chilly and it was threatening to rain. We only stayed maybe an hour and a half, but we were able to hang out with Ed A., his friend, and Adam F. Adam was kind enough to share his Stawski beer with me. You cannot fully enjoy all that Poland has to offer without a beer. Trust me!I didn't have a chance to look through every nook and cranny of Taste of Polonia, but what I saw showed me that they did a pretty good job. I just would have liked a little more Polonia for a little cheaper. I mean, there was a taqueria and some Italian food there. That's not Polish! Not even close. And while the band I saw was pretty good, it was just rock cover songs. Again, not so Polish.C'mon Copernicus Center! I know you can do better than that! I don't just want a taste. I want the whole enchilada, erm... kielbasa!

21.description: On labor day weekend there is nothing better than to grab some pierogis, potato pancakes, stuffed cabbage and a polish beer, watch some cover bands, or polka bands or my fave this year a polish metal band.  This is an amazing festival for people watching, all kinds of people flock to this...

17.description: Beautiful, beautiful theatre.  Spectacular even...

 How ingenious!2) This year the festival adopted the popular concept of refillable mugs.  For $7, you could purchase a plastic mug and have it refilled for $4 all four-day weekend (beers were normally $5).  That is, if you could find someone who spoke enough English to sell you the mug.  When I wandered up to get mine, I asked for the mug three times with increasing volume (and more and more exaggerated hand gestures in mug-like shapes) as the seller looked at me and my cohort blankly and responded with a thickly accented, "mug?"  Finally, one of his co-workers tapped him on the shoulder and whispered something in his ear (probably in Polish).  A look of recognition crossed his face.  He went to the back of the stand and brought back and empty mug and handed me a cup of beer.  Not exactly environmentally conscious (but Poland is an industrial country) but it turned out to reveal a secret.  The savings for the mug refills was minimal because the mug did not hold as much beer as the $5 cup.  How ingenious - of the organizers to pull a fast one on the crowd (it is a great mug though).Still, this festival is the craziest, most fun in the city despite its difficulties.  The oddness of some of the attendees makes this a people-watching zoo!  From aged hippies to polka-dancing old country folks to the creepiest duck mascot ever (PolTel's costumed representative) wandering the crowd scaring small children (and me) the festival is an eye catching treat.Plus the music is incredible.  They dig deep to find cover bands the other festivals won't touch (Libido Funk Circus is a hilarious party anthem band) and bring over Polish stars.  And there's plenty of polka if that floats your boat or rolls your barrel.  There's even a more subdued stage inside the Copernicus Center with choral acts and dance troupes.If they bring back Okocim as a sponsor and official beer and if they keep finding ways to Polish (er polish) it up, next year it might even be better.  Even if they don't, you can't help but admire the inventiveness of Poland in Chicago.

5.description: Great place for a concert parking is an issue but that's at any,concert.. Do not park your car on cvs pharmacy next door they will told you they have people watching and the calling towing on you

3.description: If you are looking at the space as a potential wedding venue, run. I worked with Erick B. and he was terrible. I thought we were going to be able to use the venue--the Annex. It is a really wonderful space. Erick seemed to be helpful in e-mails. Really, when it came down to it, Erick has no event experience and no experience executing contracts for weddings.Our biggest problem was that we weren't given straight answers about their bar packages. We were told switching out alcohol that's on their standard package wouldn't be a problem as long as we use their distributors. What they don't tell you is how much they'll mark up prices. Price mark-ups are totally understandable, however, we were never told what we would be paying ahead of time and a 300% mark up seems unreasonable. Had we known this up front, we would have not signed a contract with Copernicus. Erick assured us ordering different beers/alcohol than what they have wouldn't be a problem. The best part was that he ended our conversation by telling us we were his first wedding and he really didn't know all the answers. That is one area I will not argue with him.If you're prepared to have to chase him down and hold his hand through everything, then go with Copernicus. The space is reasonably priced. Just be prepared to follow-up with him.

35.description: Michael Jackson is greater than Chris BrownGI Joe the cartoon is greater than GI Joe the movie (I can see into the future)The Real World first season is greater than any Real World after SFThey don't make 'em like they used to.The old Gateway was re-named, refurbished and transformed into the Copernicus Center and the place is something to behold.  It's a beautiful and versatile building that houses concerts, plays and anything else that might need a touch of class.  Admittedly, walking in, I was tempted to run around like a little kid.  Y'see, I have always had a thing for well-designed, wide-open spaces.  It makes me happy.  I don't know why.  And there's a lot to make me happy here.  The long lobby stands guard to a gorgeous theater space.  With ample seating and balcony views, I don't think there's a bad seat in the place.  But you might not be able to concentrate on the stage when there's frosty beers (and other drinks) to be consumed (in glasses!!), dramatic chandeliers at which to marvel and woodwork etchings to study.  The entire center is a throwback to when people gave a da[rn] about their craft and buildings told stories & prompted conversation.  From its giant towers gleaming with Polish pride to its inside of grand staircases, dramatic loges, grandma cabinetry, big stages, comfy carpets and a full, old-timey bar, you'll be transported back to a time when Glen Miller played, songs made the hit parade and [old white guys with bad attitudes] had it made. Hmm.  I guess not everything changes.

19.description: Apparently the Pierogi fest in Whiting, IN is better...Even if you can't take your beer outside of the bar area. And for some reason, it's always cold for this festival. Anyway, this is the place to be for all things Polish...Food, beer, people, music, etc...

28.description: I have been here before several times for my niece's dance recitals. On Saturday night I went to see a concert, Beata Bajm with my girlfriend and I have to say the music was awesome and as the Copernicus Center is a small venue, every seat is a good seat and close to the stage. I would come back for a concert in the future!!

45.description: I went last year, had a blast, met some nice people and loved the BEERthe tribute bands were awesome!  I can hear Jimmy Hendrix tunes now from my house ( 1.5 blocks away )and I can see the fest from my back porch.. I'm putting my shoes on NOW :)

33.description: I'll be the first to admit I wasn't super psyched about going to Taste of Polonia since I'm not a big fan of Polish food. What I discovered is that the food is only one part, a small one, of the overall fest. This year is ToP's 30th Anniversary. The festival is hosted in the area surrounding the Copernicus Center. The Center, originally the Gateway Theater, was built in 1930 and was the first movie theater in Chicago built exclusively for the "talkies" and becoming home to the Polish Cultural Center in 1979. The festival runs all through Labor Day weekend (Monday too) and has five stages - two for music, one for dance music (mostly polka), one for kids, and multi-purpose stage inside the Center. Many of the bands are cover bands with Polish roots, like the reggae band Rebel Roots. There are many booths selling everything from cheesy Polish tchotchkes like t-shirts that say "stop staring at my pierogies," to sunglasses, to jewelry. Inside the Center they had a casino, various acts on the stage, and a bar; outside they also had some carnival games. I had a good time, the people watching alone is priceless. The stages had plenty of seating making it easy to eat or just take a load off. They were also pretty generous with the length of sets, each act got approximately 2 hours to perform! The beer tent offered a souvenir mug option and discounted refills too. The only reason I'm giving this fest 3.5 stars is: * No Okocim beer, it's like the Miller of Polish beers. * Tickets required for food and drinks are only sold in $5 increments, but food/drink isn't priced in $5 increments. I felt like a drug dealer helping an old lady out by trading $2 in tickets for cash. * Food choices, I was expecting more of a variety of vendors. Aside from Kasia's there was one other Polish food vendor. Maybe Pierogi Fest spoiled me. * PolTel's goose mascot creeped me out. They had multiple people dressed as them milling through the Taste. ToP is convenient to public transportation, the Blue line and Metra's Jefferson Park stop is just steps from the fest and the Milwaukee bus will drop you right there too. Check it out!

43.description: Being an American mutt, but new to the neighborhood, I couldn't NOT go to the biggest fest in my area.  Started on Friday night (which is when we went) and ended on Monday.Admission:  "Suggested donation" of $6/each, kids under 12 (I think) were free.  My hubby saw a sign in the ticket booth saying, "If someone hassles you about the admission, just give them a ticket."  On our way out, the ticket taker / security guy asked if we were coming back tonight and I replied no, but maybe the next day.  He replied, "Oh sorry, that's another $6."  Thanks bud.  Food:  Good mix of Polish food, but as someone else mentioned, a little pricey.  But hey, it is a festival.  We spent about $15 for a combo plate and some extra pierogis, which fed the two of us, with a few bites taken by my finicky toddlers.  Overall, really yummy stuff.Music:  Lucky us, we were there on "Disco Polo" day, which we correctly assumed to be Polish Disco.  Sat down at the only open table around to eat and we soon experienced the genre...at about jet-plane decibels.  Quickly ate and wandered over to the "oompa band" - more traditional music that was a bit more palatable to our and our kids' ears.  Topped off the evening by seeing an Elvis impersonator, complete with a trio of backup chick singers.  My husband rolled his eyes, but I LOVE this stuff.Games / Booths:  Variety of stuff, from lots of banks to colleges to the requisite phone service vendors.  Plus tons of Polish t-shirts, flags, mugs, etc.  Few carny games - we played one with our toddler and he won a little animal, the guy was really nice.Summary:  Not sure it was worth $12 for us to experience about an hour of Polish music and walk through vendors to buy Polish food (when I can get it at half-dozen restaurants in the area.)  BUT, I did get a flyer saying that early afternoons - noon to 3, I think, were free, and it seems like there were bands playing all day, so next year, that will be the plan.

2.description: I really need to come to the Copernicus Center for something more than the Taste of Polonia. That said, I love the Taste of Polonia, aka Polish Fest. Fun times, lots of stages, good Polish beer and lots of food.The Copernicus Center is one of Chicago's older, really cool theaters. Nice but uncomfortable seats. They have balconies, etc. The ceiling is starry. Way cool. Lots of stalls in the ladies room. There is a bar and some side room that at the fest, they use as a poker room - for funds raising, of course.

18.description: Polish MayFest Chicago9th Annual weekend-long Polish Festival celebrating Polish Constitution Day with great Polish food, special activities just for kids, nonstop world music on indoor & outdoor stages and fun for all ages... May 5-6th, 2012 at the Copernicus Center. YAY!

41.description: This has become my fave street fair in Chicago. Three stages, Okochim beer everywhere (not my favorite but better than the standard Bud), and food that is outta this world.  You can see polka bands, polish jam bands, and modern rock cover bands all in one square block, and do it while downing some top-notch polish sausage, perogis, and blintzes.  And make no mistake, this is still a predominantly Polish festival...you're gettin' the real deal here.

4.description: I had my daughter's baptism party there. Great people to work with, everything came out beautiful.

6.description: While I've not experienced the many festivals that Copernicus Center seems to be famous for, I can tell you that as a concert venue, it's pretty great.Went here Friday night see one of my favorite bands play and this was a venue they'd never played in before, so I was anxious to check it out. The ingress could have flowed more smoothly as there weren't designated lines and folks kind of shoved in where they could, but I'm a seasoned concert goer so it didn't faze me. Initially it was difficult to find our seats and even the people that worked there couldn't really tell us what section we were in (apparently the "bronze" section doesn't really exist), but we did manage to find them on our own. The main area is beautiful, with dark blue ceilings and lights that resemble twinkling stars (well, Copernicus was the Father of Modern Astronomy). Chandeliers, statues, and other dramatic touches transport you to another era. Lovely.Acoustics were great, and since our seats were right near one of the exit doors, we were able to make a quick getaway after the show.Parking will run you about $10 if you're not lucky enough to find metered street parking.I will definitely be back to CC to see a show or attend a festival. Hell, maybe I'll even swing by here to see the Pope should he ever come back to Chicago (as one of my friends did here back in '79).The only negative is that ever since I bought my tickets online from the Copernicus Center, I've been inundated with emails in Polish and I can't seem to unsubscribe from them. I wish they would stop; no mowimy po polsku.

22.description: Went here for the Taste of Polonia on Monday.  Nice facility.

15.description: Yesterday I attended a concert at copernicus for a polish star Maryla Rodowicz. It was by far the worst experience I ever had. They offered VIP tickets for 100 dollars each which included open bar, balcony seats and most importantly meeting and pictures with the star. First, open bar only consisted of beer and wine, drinks were extra which was not mentioned. Second, after the concert was over Maryla started giving autographs to people who were standing in line which were the people that paid 50 dollars for no special offers. The staff told us to wait in a seperate room till she is finished and she will come to the room and we will be able to hang out with her and take pictures. She finished autographing and disappeared after. We were then told that Maryla is tired and is unable to come out to see the VIP crowd and to come back tomorrow for an autograph and picture. Needless to say, we paid double for tickets and we didn't get a picture nor an autograph but yet the people who paid half as much got all of that. Copernicus was just in for the money I'm definately never going back there again for them to steal my money. Organization of events is absolutely terrible and they have no idea how to make an event successful.

I had already missed out on one of the other large Polish festivals of the year, so this would have to hold me over until next year. I know you can find a plethora of Polish places in Chicagoland, but there's just something special about going to a venue where you know my people are going to be en mass and shine.We were not fans of the $7pp charge just to walk into the fair. Trust me!I didn't have a chance to look through every nook and cranny of Taste of Polonia, but what I saw showed me that they did a pretty good job. I just would have liked a little more Polonia for a little cheaper. I mean, there was a taqueria and some Italian food there. That's not Polish! Not even close. And while the band I saw was pretty good, it was just rock cover songs. Again, not so Polish.C'mon Copernicus Center! I know you can do better than that! I don't just want a taste. I want the whole enchilada, erm... kielbasa!

36.description: I had never even heard of this space until we popped in to see it on the neighborhood tour.Beautiful theater and they can be booked for events too.

14.description: I remember it as the Gateway Theater, Its great for a concert

3.description: I bought a Groupon for cut, highlights and style. Maria was beyond great at doing my hair and being friendly. I can definitely say i have found a salon I will stick with. Loved it

1.description: I am a little late adding this review but saw negative comments and felt compelled to do it. I went there August of 2014 and had a groupon for highlights, cut, and style. When I arrived I must say I was disappointed at the esthetics of the salon...to say the least but I stayed.I am glad I did because Maria did an awesome job! I had highlights done only one other time in my life and that was a bust! I waited over ten years to try them again because it was done so poorly. Anyways, Maria listened to my needs and talked about both how I wanted it to look like and what I DID NOT WANT it to look like. I seriously came out with a big grin in my face and overjoyed by how much I liked my highlights! Highly recommend.I will add that Maria is what I would call "old school" so don't be taken back by that because it does not do her skills justice...just saying.I did recommend this place to my sister and she did just informed me that there line is disconnected...not sure what's going on with that.

0.description: What a great place. Maria is absolutely superb and full of personality and does a fabulous job cutting hair.I purchased a groupon for a 25 dollar haircut (originally 35) and Maria was able to see me after the groupon expired and still honored it. She's not a stylist who butchers hair and she listens to what you want. Sure. she has a creative edge and will input what she thinks may look nice, but for what I asked for she listened attentively and gave me exactly what I wanted.I will be going back here again. GREAT PLACE.

2.description: Maria is seriously the best! She is great at what she does and will never disappoint her clients! I've been coming to her for years and have never had a bad experience. She is hilarious and will keep you entertained while your color sets!

5.description: First time at studio 23 was kinda worried about going to a new place but I Love my hair. So I found my new Togo salon. The fastest n beautiful work done in a little over an hour by Maria. Used a groupon but will pay full price next time. This Salon is far from where I live but worth it.

6.description: I got my hair cut here, and was not impressed. The stylist told me that her husband had gotten a vasectomy. I didn't need to know that! The cut was okay, but nothing great. I haven't gone back to this place.

7.description: I heart this place! I actually have not had a same hair dresser before I came here. I feel that Maria has tried to understand my style and hair from the first time. I usually let the hair stylist create whatever they thought would fit my style... and I believe this woman did the job!! I will keep going back to her for a long long time.

8.description: Walked into here on a whim thanks to Groupon. The outside isn't much to look at and I was having a bad day so I considered not going. Glad I did! Greeted right when I came in the door with a friendly face and told, "I'll be with you in a few, just finishing up here." So many places fail to acknowledge people. Kelly was my stylist and she did wonderful. I was there for a cut, style and blow dry. I didn't know the kind of cut I wanted and Kelly decided on one that would go well with my face shape. I don't normally conversate with stylists but we were bantering the whole time. My hair turned our great and I am definitely happy. I will surely return for another hair styling completed by Kelly!

9.description: I have been a client of Maria's for a very long time! She is an amazing colorist and is really creative with up-dos. I have been a bridesmaid 17 times and she has come up with different looks each time! My hair is always the look that withstands at the end of the wedding. I am blonde and she does really great highlights that I am always complimented on. Prices are very reasonable and the salon is welcoming.

10.description: Looking for a place to get your hair done for that special occasion? Stop by Studio 23's convenient northwest side location and they will cater to your needs. Mrs. Benincasa and her friendly staff will do whatever you want and add a special touch of elegance to your hair. You'll even get a free back massage while you're waiting, or you can look through the countless style books to pass your time.

4.description: I bought the Groupon because of other people reviews...and feel obligated to share my experience. When I arrived and saw the place, I wasn't sure if the address was correct. It was so disgusting I didn't know if I should walk in or just run away. The place was EMPTY. Nobody was there except one woman sitting behind the desk. She looked like she didn't shower for a week, and her hair was kind of...gross. Her clothes were stained and dirty. I considered running away again.  I stayed-told her to just do the highlights, no haircut (I was to scare to let her touch my hair). While she was doing the color, I listened to her stories about her family, and life on buzz (!!!!!!!!). I guess, she tried to be nice. And I'm sure, there's an audience for that kind of trash stories too.  I was thinking- maybe it's not too late, maybe I can still run away. She also cut the ends of my hair (that quite shorten the hair; just the ends?). The styling done at the end was just brushing my hair with flat brush while blow-drying! The next day I noticed a lot of green hint in my hair color. After few weeks it washed out, and I don't see any highlights at all. The bathroom? Bathrooms at the gas stations in the middle of nowhere that haven't been remodeled for 70 years look better. And they call it A STUDIO? At its best its third world country barber shop. I wish I run away. Never again.

1.description: Never had a bad meal here. Breakfast is amazing, gyro platter is huge, but this place will serve you the best grilled ham and cheese of your life. Simple and delicious.

9.description: This place is definitely better then the previous place. Good Italian beefs and love the fries. Prices are good as well.

23.description: First, I'll admit I'm biased. My sister works there as a waitress. But if you care about not only high quality food but good people to support, a personal recommendation can't be all bad, right? The owners are really good bosses to her, always supportive and I've heard a lot about their high standards for the food they create.The soups are homemade by "Mama G" and the gyro meat is selected for the best flavor and lower fat content. I've had sandwiches, skillets, soups, and salads. All were generous portions, reasonably priced, and really delicious. I'm adding my pictures to the page here too, so you can see the sizes and details too.

5.description: Perfect spot being so close to the Jefferson park blue line.The inside is clean and classic diner looking with a few photos on the wall of the old jefferson park train stop.You order by the door (cash only) and then find yourself a seat and wait.I thought they would call my order but they bring it out to you and even filled my fountain drink for me (literally never had that done for me before), talk about service!I'm pretty sure it's family run, and that the family is the nicest family ever.Food was pretty good, classic diner dishes. I ordered the 3 eggs and corned beef hash.Came with the largest side of potatoes ever. I wish I got a little more hash and less potatoes, but besides that it was amazing.They do put a decent amount of butter on their toast so if that's not your thing, be sure to ask for no butter or butter on the side when you order.

25.description: This what is a great little hot dog stand right of the Jefferson Park Blue Line train stop and bus station. This place has all new construction including a brand new kitchen. They are located in the former Freddy's Fast Food location. The staff is very friendly and some of the staff also worked under the previous owner. We had our breakfast there twice this week, the ham egg and cheese sandwich! They have delicious sandwiches and there prices are reasonable! I would suggest closing at 12am because many ohare workers get off at 11pm!

12.description: Changed  owners a few years  ago  but the food is still good maybe  a little better this is a little dive of a diner big portions and low prices its quick and good

21.description: This place and the people who run it are gems.I work close to here and come about once if not twice a week for lunch.I am a meatloaf fanatic so I decided to try it one day. It was very salty and I did not eat it, I just ate the mashed potatoes. Unbeknownst (like that big word, dontcha?)  to me, they had noticed that I didn't eat it. So the next morning my co-worker went in to pick up her breakfast and they told her to tell me to come back for lunch and it was on them. I thought that was so nice and I didn't expect it. They really value and care about their customers.Every soup that I have tried is GREAT.Polish with grilled onions=Great.Reasonably priced and they have great specials.Friendly faces.

16.description: Great food and the new owners have done well by this place. The owners are great and the staff friendly and courteous.  My favorite server is Korissa, she is not only gorgeous but she's an awesome young lady. Kudos JP grill!!

17.description: This place and the people who run it are gems.I work close to here and come about once if not twice a week for lunch.I am a meatloaf fanatic so I decided to try it one day. It was very salty and I did not eat it, I just ate the mashed potatoes. Unbeknownst (like that big word, dontcha?)  to me, they had noticed that I didn't eat it. So the next morning my co-worker went in to pick up her breakfast and they told her to tell me to come back for lunch and it was on them. I thought that was so nice and I didn't expect it. They really value and care about their customers.Every soup that I have tried is GREAT.Polish with grilled onions=Great.Reasonably priced and they have great specials.Friendly faces.

10.description: Pretty good for the greasy spoon diner variety. Price was in par for most other diners, but the amount of food I got was ridiculous. Close to 2 lbs of potatoes and a massive omelette. No way I could eat it all. The I side was a lot nicer than the outside would leave to believe. Friendly staff and my to go order was ready in 5 minutes. Can't complain!

11.description: After reading the reviews, I decided to come here for lunch. I ordered the Jefferson Skillet and my boyfriend ordered an Italian beef with fries. Portions were huge and delicious. I will be back for sure!

26.description: This new grill opened up in the Jefferson Park bus terminal. I saw it in the local paper.I had the hot dog special. Two hot dogs and an order of fries.The hot dogs were good. I didn't care so much for the pickle, it was the sweeter type.The fries were good. They are your typical frozen fries. I did enjoy them.The place is clean inside and had about 7 tables.The people were very nice and friendly. I look forward to returning.

22.description: This place can only be described as a gem. I have walked past it many times over the years (remember when it used to be called the Terminal Diner?) but had never stopped in until today. It's bigger inside than it appears from the outside and surprisingly clean. I had the biscuits and gravy. Delicious with real pieces of sausage in the gravy!  Only complaint was no decaf coffee but I'm sure I'm in the minority there. The restroom was modern and clean (albeit oddly situated) and the waitress was pleasant and efficient. I'll be back again for sure.

0.description: Jefferson Park Grill is the best. Decent prices, fast service, clean and modern interior. Owner Mike is on the grill, in sight, greeting regulars every morning into the afternoon. The girl taking your order on register is the same person bringing to table your food. Always pleasant. Quick in and out, especially with call ahead for takeout.For less dollars than Micky D's across Milwaukee you can get a better meal here made out of real food.Daily soups are the real thing as well, hearty and loaded with cabbage, or chicken chunks, or rice, or whatever good stuff depending on the soup of the day.

20.description: I work around the corner from here. As a bit of a food snob, I'd written them off as a greasy spoon, until I read the Yelp reviews and decided to give it a shot. I'm so glad I did! The people who work here are super friendly, the food is humble Greek diner fare PERFECTED, and the amount of food they give you for what you pay is absurd. I "complained" once, "You always give me too much food," and the response was, "We'd rather have you leave too full than still hungry."

19.description: I like new place more like the old one long time ago I also know owner  i will do a lot of work for this guy Good luck to you :-)

2.description: Nice little food place in Jeff Park buss terminal. They have great prices and the young lady whom takes your order is very nice. ( Mary).Tgey have everything from eggs to steak to pork chops,hot dogs,burgers ect.They will be undergoibg a face lift soon so will be closed temporarily from Aug 31st to Sept. Something.My only complaint is that when I order my eggs over easy,I want them over easy. More times than not they come over med. However its not a deal breaker because their prices and abundant portions are well worth it.All in all a great lil neighborhood stomp.

18.description: This new grill opened up in the Jefferson Park bus terminal. I saw it in the local paper.I had the hot dog special. Two hot dogs and an order of fries.The hot dogs were good. I didn't care so much for the pickle, it was the sweeter type.The fries were good. They are your typical frozen fries. I did enjoy them.The place is clean inside and had about 7 tables.The people were very nice and friendly. I look forward to returning.

13.description: It's what you expect from a restaurant stand near the CTA.  Can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

4.description: I only get to come here if I open as it is closed after I get here.  Awesome place, clean and tidy inside, and the cashier Veronica is awesome as hell, very friendly.

24.description: Wow! This is what we needed in Jefferson park! Finally a place that has good food with lots of variety! And very affordable! It deserves 5 stars based on cleanliness all on its own! Friendly staff that remembers you and chats with you every time you return, like they are welcoming you into their own home.Dine in or carry out! Also if you do dine in, you get actual dinnerware and silverware opposed to paper, which is a huge plus! Oh and gotta have the soup, especially the lentil!

6.description: The outside somehow intimidates you from going on but once you step on you see a very clean location The staff was friendly and helpful The pancakes were amazing and the hash browns are home made just like the pancakes This won't be my last time visiting

15.description: First, I'll admit I'm biased. My sister works there as a waitress. But if you care about not only high quality food but good people to support, a personal recommendation can't be all bad, right? The owners are really good bosses to her, always supportive and I've heard a lot about their high standards for the food they create.The soups are homemade by "Mama G" and the gyro meat is selected for the best flavor and lower fat content. I've had sandwiches, skillets, soups, and salads. All were generous portions, reasonably priced, and really delicious. I'm adding my pictures to the page here too, so you can see the sizes and details too.

7.description: I wish Yelp allowed multiple reviews for a business...First, your experience will depend on the people who serve you.Second, their mood can vary.Third, you mood can vary too.I was in a good mood. I was trying to make a small talk with the girl cashier.- You Polish?- No.- Germany I guess?- No, I'm from here.It's okay, some people don't like being asked about their "wherefroms".Now, I ordered the Maxwell Street sausage and left generous tips, was trying to cheer her up a little.Her face expression didn't show nothing.I asked to pour me a glass of water and put it in the microwave for 15 seconds to make it lukewarm. The girl refused to do that, saying that hard plastic cup is not microwave safe... My fucking god, you kidding me???I didn't give up easily but my god.. she was like a robot. I even explained, I need that for my sore throat.. So I say okay, I'll get the water and you can deduct its price from my tip.Now her face was like "you serious?"You're not from here, Polish b*ch! Be nice with your customers!

8.description: I pass by this place everyday on my way to work and it reminds me of those dives you'd see in rough neighborhoods which always brings back fond memories of me ordering food next to crackheads and drug dealers, overhearing funny (usually very vulgar) conversations and watching the constant fights break out. Each time I walked by Jefferson Park Grill I etched into my mind that I'd eventually venture forth through that door, chatting up the patrons and possibly getting into a fight.One day after work, the time was ripe since I got off earlier. I came in around 7:00 waving to the lady smoking on the steps outside, we shared a momentary smile. As I walked in I noticed it was small, quaint space, maybe 1-2 people working the kitchen, but the cashier was nowhere to be found. I hear an "excuse me baby" and as I step aside the woman that was smoking on the steps passes by and hops up to the cash register to my surprise. Looking at the menu I got hungry for a good Philly cheese steak and a pizza puff with some OJ. The cashier was nice and worked it so that she replaced the drink that came with my pizza puff combo with the higher priced OJ without charging me extra for the OJ. She then asked me where I was going to sit and brought me my juice. I took the time to look around while I was there. There are a few wooden tables, a tv, atm, with some pictures on the wall of celebrities that I assumed visited before. The place was clean as a whistle and the only customers inside were me and another guy (who was also dressed in a suit like myself which prompted some glaring.)After waiting around 10 minutes she brought my sandwich, fries and pizza puff. To my delight this Philly steak looked freaking amazing with perfectly melted cheese blended with peppers and nicely toasted bread. It's almost as if they prepared it for a commercial shoot. The pizza puff made me ecstatic as well since it's not your typical crappy frozen puff you get at most restaurants. The puff they serve is full of meat, cheese, sauce, and bigger than the usual ones along with being cooked perfectly as well. Everything tasted great. The Philly disappointed me a bit because they didn't prepare it like a usual Philly (no mayo or anything extra, just cheese and peppers.) So it didn't have that unique Philly taste. The cashier stopped by frequently checking in and making sure everything was good with me, even bringing me ketchup and telling me I was the best dressed customer she'd ever seen (which prompted the other guy to leave in what I can only assume was a fit of jealousy.)The cook stepped out for a bit and went outside the back door to wash a bucket. Meanwhile the cashier opened the bathroom door to find a half naked crackhead doing god knows what inside there. He came out a few minutes later, starting chatting and causing a small scene with all his twitching and barely intelligible speech while trying to order a sandwich that wasn't even on the menu. Eventually he settled on an egg and sausage sandwich coupled with a coffee before he made his way to Jefferson Park station to beg for money. Fun times.Overall a good place to visit. I'd say expect a good presentation and not your usual spin on things. Good food, great prices. Don't settle for Dunkin Donuts, Mcdonalds, etc. when you can visit this place.*This place is CASH ONLY. There's an ATM inside and a PNC one at the Jefferson Park Station.

3.description: Pretty good value.  It's exactly what you would expect.  Burgers, Hot Dogs, and other diner food.  I like that it's right off the Jefferson Park Blue line stop, so I can grab a quick bite if I'm coming home from work late and in a hurry.

14.description: I like to support local businesses especially when there is a McDonalds across the street. However, I will Not be returning! The cashier was cold and unfriendly not something I want to deal with during a long commute to work. Most importantly the food made me so sick I had to leave work early. One time only customer!

3.description: I have a mohawk. Not a difficult hairstyle to cut! All the woman had to do was follow the outline I already had and she couldn't even do that. The only reason I stopped in was because I recently broke my wrist and it's difficult for me to hold a razor that long to shave my own head.  That's all this woman had to do was shave my freakin' head.  However, she managed to f*** it all up. There's about an 1/8 of an in around my mohawk that she missed even after I asked her to fix it. To top it off...it's crooked as holy hell! I went back for my money because now I have to spend the day fixing something I should have done myself.A monkey could have done a better job.Do not go here if you don't want to look like you just gave a scissor to a 3 year old to cut your hair!!!

1.description: Honestly, I used to go here all the time and be content with my haircut. The guy and two women who've been there for years all do a pretty good job considering I'm a guy who just wants short enough hair to style.But the last two times I've gone, a new lady has cut my hair, and managed to scalp me in some spots and then leave mountain tufts of hair in other places. I don't mean to be rude, but come on. No matter how I style it, I can only put it to one side, no joke, same exact haircut Hitler got on his 39th birthday.I have extreme anxiety and the fact I have no control over my hair drives me insane. I told her what I wanted but she gave me something completely the opposite. I walked out with a mowhawk and gel. I'm an 18 year old Caucasian (I'm half Mexican but have white skin) male. Don't give me the haircut of a 7 year old Mexican boy.I don't know who she is, but I probably shouldn't have sat down in that chair when the person she had just finished cutting had a shaved head, and quite frankly, his bald head with all those scars looks better than my hair as of now.So I'm shaving my head because I fear if I let it grow out, some spots are so bald, and some are so long, growing it out will lead to two ponytails on the sides of my head.Lady, if you are reading this, take it as good criticism. Go to Germany, and cut their hair because you are only good at shaving heads and Hitler haircuts.

2.description: TerribleThe Hispanic man that cuts hair there has messed up my hair a total of three timesToday was the worst of it he completely messed up my hair and when I told him it was wrong he refused to fix it and said that he's going to charge me for 2 haircuts if he fixes itManagement still made me pay for my haircutThe girls are great he needs to be fired

5.description: Five dollars for a ten minute hair cut. The staff is very friendly and thoughtful, and they will actually listen to specific instructions. Not only do they speak fluent English (a rarity in a cheap haircut place) but I have also heard conversations in Polish and Spanish. I'm not saying this is the kind of place where you would go for a haircut before that big wedding or court date, but for a guy that wants a quick and neatly done clipper job, this is the best place.It is conveniently located near the Jefferson Park train and bus monstrosity

6.description: Love this place. Wafa is my very own hairstylist, and she takes very very good care of me. So affordable, and the more you go and build up that customer loyalty to her, the better. So affordable compared to these other salons that cost an arm an a leg for a haircut, and heaven forbid I want to be on time for rent money should I need new highlights. Ambiance is zero, it's just a little hair shop. $5 threading / waxing / haircut. Tell Wafa I sent you! :)

7.description: Dashmire is the best.  I have problem hair and she cuts it so nice and I have a nice color too.  Thank you.

0.description: I'm a cheap dude on a cheap budget, and I've been looking for a cheap place to get a simple haircut. Fortunately for me, my haircut is pretty simple, and in the end, it's just hair to me. This place is located half a block away from the giant Jefferson Park Blue Line CTA depot.The setup is somewhat small, seats less than 10-people. No-frills place for your fades and simple hair cutting needs. The people here are friendly, although quite honestly, not sure if they are super fluent in English.Pro tip: You may already have been advised of this, but bring a picture of the 'do you are aiming for. Pictures speak a thousand words, even especially if you think there may be a language barrier.

4.description: Nothing wrong with this place at all.  For a $5 haircut, I'm not expecting miracles or salon quality.  I've got a pretty straight forward haircut, so I can't speak to more complicated styles like a mohawk.  They have competent staff and usually a short wait.  Great alternative to Betty and Nick's.

3.description: We get a lot of our meat from here. The burgers and steaks are great. Got a ham for Christmas and again it was a winner. Just made prime rib tonight and it was Amazing! Will never order one for dinner at a restaurant again and pay an insane price per plate.

1.description: My fraternal organization has been using Ellengee for years.  They have excellent meat products and make their hamburgers fresh daily.  We have ordered over 300 lbs of corned beef every year for years from them to cook for our St. Patrick's Day party, and most say it's the BEST they've ever had.  Their burgers are excellent and we use those every year at our annual picnic.  They offer a wide variety of meet products and you can view them online at ellengeemarket.com .  They also offer a wide variety of e great steaks and some really kicking thick cut bacon.  If you're a meet lover, do yourself a favor and check them out.  773.777.9000

2.description: i recently purchased a corned beef brisket from here .......TOP SHELF QUALITY MEATS ...... the brisket was amazingly priced. far cheaper than grocery stores it was like 14 pounds for $38 ...... also the guy who helped us was very knowledgeable..... also you can call in your order and they'll have it ready for you to come and pick it up...........on my way there now to grab some burgers and a beef brisket.

0.description: This place is outstanding!  Restaurant quality meats at wholesale prices.  Very knowledgeable and friendly staff.  Buy local here for your next cook out instead of Sam's or Costco.  Quality is the same or better, prices are cheaper, employees are more hands on, and you are buying from and supporting a local business.  Everyone wins!  Except Sam's or Costco.  But they will be ok.  They win enough...

4.description: This place does more wholesale meat delivery to restaurants in the area but found a flyer that it has recently started a cash n carry so I decided to try it out .  I bought a few things from here ........ mind you that you cant just buy 1 steak or 1 chicken leg... you have to buy it in somewhat a bulk but the quality is great and the prices are right.....so Ive been buying 5lb boxes of 1/2 lb burgers for my bbqs and have never had a problem and will continue to do my bulk meat shopping here and support a local business instead of costco.

58.description: As other reviews have stated, it's not a particularly rewarding experience unless you are in need of authentic Polish grocery/deli items.However, they do have the cheapest selection of Polish beers in the area and that's a good enough reason for me to stop in on occasion.  Or more often.

56.description: So far I've only been here once. The trek from Jeff Park to Lincoln Square to go to Lincoln Quality Meats is getting long, so I've been trying to find an "every day" butcher closer to home.Pluses: interesting selection, that is, if you're into Polish versions of normal groceries (the Vitiminka was good); limited vegetable selection, but the ones they have looked good, and many were local (Illinois grown); pickles in large barrels (need I say more?)Mehs: good frozen pirogi, but they have MSG in them; had poppy seed cake, but it was a little dry; is there really much difference among the Polish beers they have? big meat selection, but as noted before, they call your number in Polish. Now, how's that gonna help my German ass?Minuses: there should be a big sign saying "Warning, every guy in this place and some of the women will stare at your wife's T&A for at least three minutes"; if you buy something written completely in Polish, and you expect it to be pickled beets because of the big red chunks floating in the beet red brine, and it turns out to be a pickled herring pirogi and you hate fish... well, that's just your own stupid fault...

29.description: great deli... has the freshest meat in all of chicago and awesome polish food

42.description: There is street parking and 2 lots, the additional lot is like 3 buildings south, clearly marked. If the street and both lots are full, the place will be packed. Weekends are always crazy busy....why? Because they have great food at good prices. Lots of "specialty shop" stuff at Jewel prices. Most all employees speak at least the minimum amount of English. During the week is not so busy. If you are a princess who wants the shop keeper to kiss your feet for stopping by, you will be greatly disappointed. If you want great food at a good price, stop by and check it out.

23.description: I am half Polish but non-Polish speaking and live a block away. I don't go here unless I have a craving for stuffed cabbage or homemade chicken noodle soup. Never really had an issue asking staff for assistance and though they're not overly friendly, they are certainly not rude by any means. It's hysterical that there is a drop-box outside the exit labeled "Customer Complaints" situated directly beneath a security camera.

47.description: The ham was excellent and the potato pancakes were good , but i attest to everyone's testimony that if you dont speak the polish language you will not have the best customer service experience at this place, they looked at me weird as if I was bothering them, I really wanted to yelp at the Deli dispatcher by yelping at the top of my lungs,  "CAN I PLEASE HAVE A POUND OF KRAKUS HAM AND MAKE IT FREAKIN PAPER THIN" but then again she wouldnt understand a word i just said. oooh well back to Tony finer foods for some Krakus ham I go.

8.description: Homemade fresh daily polish delicacies and the fresh veal, pork, beef, chicken,duck, and fresh or smoked fish is by far the best deli in Chicagoland area! Been to deli's all over and this is the best! Check out the cafe and treat yourself to a juicy steak! Hot off the grill!

31.description: I love this place, the hot counter is wonderful, the best butter I have ever eaten, however; I think the people that work there need to speak more English...THIS IS AMERICA!!! Not everyone that shops there is polish some of us are AMERICAN!! I GIVE IT ONLY 3 STARS BUT 5 stars for the food service not so good!!!

34.description: We had the pleasure to finally find Andy's deli.  The deli counter is well stocked with meats and cheeses that are fresh and nicely presented.  I do have an advantage of speaking Polish, but didn't feel it was a requirement as the numbering system and the food were well labeled.  I was impressed with the selection and cleanliness of the store.  We will definitely be back.  The hot foods counter is amazing, too.  It was crowded on a Saturday, but I consider it to be a good sign that so many people find this store exceptional.  After shopping we stopped at the bakery next door for a little treat.  Paczki, sekacz, kremowki, eklerki.... all the goodness from my childhood in Warszawa.  My boys loved it! (oh, and I was amused by the reviewers that were annoyed with the 'Polishness' of the store.. yes, it was pretty Polish for a Polish deli!)

16.description: Authentic, packed with pretty much everything Polish you could want, but definitely poorly organized at the checkout line. Even without worrying about parking, the checkout was enough to make us not buy anything. Not super helpful or friendly, as above mentioned.

13.description: Disgustingly rude staff. They take extraordinary pleasure in passive aggressiveness. Rolling eyes, shrugging shoulders, dirty looks and that unique movement when someone who's only job is customer service goes out of their way to make it known they are annoyed having to help you. All this in the 5 mins it took me to walk in and buy a bottle of polish vodka. Great selection though. I hate you Andy's deli.

11.description: They have additional parking down the street (Milwaukee)... and yet people still try to cram the parking lot next to the building/store.

39.description: This is one of the few great Polish stores in Chicago, other than this one I only approve of one other. I live in Avondale but my mom and I make the trip to Jefferson Park to get awsome food from "Mikolajczyk" as Andy's Deli is known to Polish people. They have a great variety of FRESH deli meat which is incredibly difficult to get from most Polish stores. They have a great selection of raw meat as well. They do have the typical Polish food that most other stores have but I feel like they have a greater variety. The hot food counter is outstanding-- they have a variety of meats and especially fish that you can't get in other places as well as a great line up of homemade salads. They also make fresh carrot juice =] They recently opened an ice cream counter after the store burned down which looks amazing with 15+ flavors of whipped soft serve, unfortunately I came too early to taste any because it doesn't open until 10. In general they have a polite staff and the store is maintained very well. Delicious food. Polecam i zycze smacznego =]

37.description: I'm Polish and I know good Polish food and this place is awesome! If you ever want to cater food this place has delicious meals! We had a bday party and every person was so impressed with the food. I totally recommend Andy's Deli for anybody who wants a taste of Eastern European food. These people know how to cook!

0.description: LOVE IT! Great choice of all Polish food and drink you can wish for! They even carry some cosmetics and OTC drugs, as well as newspapers!Visiting this deli is always a  greatly anticipated highlight of all my trips to Chicago. As a Polish, I feel a great joy to be able to buy homey products and to speak my mother tongue at last! :)Be careful when picking some dairy products, they do happen to be expired!I am a great fan of their meat/deli station. Great selection of delicious sausages and really good ready dinners!  You can even have it warmed up and eat there!Nothing better than coming home from Windy City packed with all the goodies! :)

38.description: My God, what whinners!  Yes, this is nearly Polish only, no, I'm not Polish.  Why would I go?  Because they have excellent meats and deli provisions at decent prices.  The key to waiting at the deli counter is to take a number.  Most behind the counter speak enough English to understand what you want and assist you.  Great cheeses and sausages.  Worth a try for those who like Eastern European style sausages.

51.description: This place is like a super market of Polish food.  You can get all your standards here.  But unfortunately most things they make there, like the sausages and pierogi have MSG in them.  I am still looking for a real home style Polish deli convenient to my routine.

27.description: Heaven on earth for Polish folks ! They have everything you can think of Polish. I was only visiting from SF and I can only wish for a store like that. I loved it !

32.description: My favorite polish deli.

54.description: I seriously live so close that if I listen closely, I can hear the sounds of cars in their parking lot crashing into each other. Its almost a bittersweet noise to hear after you have been away for a while. Anyway, the place is clean but impossible to get some service ANYWHERE in that store if you don't speak polish. Not one word. I think the only way I got service was because my mother and I did a sign language rendition of what we needed (beef shanks....guess how we pantomimed that bad boy). I really don't want to pull the race card but I had to. The butcher took 5 customers who were polish before us, then he looked at us then we pantomimed our order, helped another non polish speaking white guy (we are asian), then he asked us what we needed again. Last I checked...it was first come...first served...guess not.Like I said the parking lot is small, selection is limited, and the meats are fresh. In order to be served, make sure you bring out that polish to english dictionary. Or you can take out that polish neighbor of yours

48.description: Good selection of pierogies and juices that may be hard to find elsewhere.  I didn't approach the deli as it is (allegedly) tough to get service if you don't speak the language.Checkout was a breeze since I paid with cash.

44.description: This is a great deli.  The fresh Polish sausage is fantastic!  I've moved away from Chicago, but I found a deli in Houston that gets its sausage from Andy's, which makes me really happy!

24.description: Chicago-Land people are spoiled with all these Polish markets.  I am a Pole in California and whenever I am in Chicago, we always come here.  I would not change a thing as it is a bit of a blast from the past and the food decent.

7.description: I went there a few days ago. Those people are so not professional. The food was not fresh! Fresh fish at home turn out to have some wired odor!  My soup tasted like an expired veggies from a a few days  ago! Not to mention stuff gossiping in their native language!!!!!!Stay away! Get your fresh groceries somewhere else. I won't return.

49.description: I went here today after hearing about it from a friend's Polish housekeeper. Man, that woman knows her food. They have sausages, baked goods, tons of pickled everything, dozens of mustards, and so many types of Kefir it will make your head spin (like most of these places in Chicago). The thing that sets this place apart for me was that they offered some classic Polish sausage made out of chicken. I have no idea, but I bet these are "healthier" versions. What basis do I have for this? None. I want to think that eating Chicken sausage is better for me! Ok, well, they also had German prosciutto which is salted then smoked  like the much rarer Austrian Speck (write me if you can find this somewhere in Chicago). I did not get anything other than the three food groups (sausage, dairy, and bread), but they have a large section of awesome looking Polish to-go foods and these looked great. The women were as friendly as Polish store women tend to be but I found my way around well enough. Got meat? Yes. Got dairy products? Yes. Got bread? Yes.  Add some cheap 6 packs of Polish sparkling water and you are good to go. Now, much of what they had can be had closer into the city between Central Park and Belmont on Milwaukee Ave. but if you live northwest of Avondale, I suggest this place highly. Do widzenia. Dobrze zje.

40.description: The only place in Chicago with really good european kind of  food. We shop there on a regular basis. Very good prices comparing to any other food store or supermarket. As an example, if we spend in Andy's Deli $200, the same kind of shopping would cost us almost $400 in another store. This place is the best for any holiday food shopping (New Year, Birthday, etc)
