53.description: OK, all I'm sayin' is, crying about a Polish deli only selling Polish food is like crying about not being able to find pierogi at Super H Mart.The parking.  Yeah, the parking lot is small.  It used to be smaller.  Park on the street.  Oh no, you might have walk a block *gasp.*The butcher doesn't speak English.  Oh well.  It's a Polish deli.  90% of their business is Polish.  You live in Chicago, why don't YOU speak Polish ;p (I kid).  Andy's is primarily "for Poles, by Poles," so if you don't speak Polish, don't be surprised if the service isn't that great.  Put the shoe on the other foot.  When someone doesn't speak English very well and asks you for help, how helpful are you?  Yeah, that's what I thought.  If you need help ordering something, ask a Polish speaking shopper to assist you, there's a good chance they'll help.  The quality of food is excellent.  The Polish sausage is good (although I like Gene's Polish sausage more) and their pierogi are just like my Babka makes 'em.

30.description: I am a first generation Pole, grown and raised in Hamtramck, MI. I now live in the Dallas/ft worth area. Often I become homesick for my Babcia cooking and Old Polish Cuisine. I ordered Polish food from Andy's Deli in Chicago. Craving Kishka, kielbasa, and kabanosy, I ordered online from Andy's. Placed my order on Sat. Expecting the order (shipped first thing Mon) to arrive on Wed. Thurs at the latest. On Sat. I knew I wouldn't see my order til Mon. I see from other posts that they are very busy, but if they offer online shipping this should be their priority before they open the store. My order was in excess of 100.00. Probably not what people spend in the store. Something's wrong with management. Hire someone to do it or don't offer it. Get yourselves more organized or don't collect money for bad goods. I'll have to order from Philly Polish distrutors from now on. Makes me sad!!!

46.description: Don't try and get near this place on a Saturday morning.  The patrons are seriously devoid of driving skills and usually will wait in line for a spot in the small lot, clogging up one lane of Milwaukee avenue, rather that park on th street or right around the corner.  Once inside you better be ready for some good ole fashioned communist era line wrestling with hard looking grannies who are probably not 50 but  must have lived a hard life before coming to America.  God bread selection, but if you end up looking like 90% of this crowd, I will pass on the sausage they eat...

1.description: Delicious polish foodThe hot side had excellent pierogis, salmon, and sauerkraut Many fresh meets and only polish beer Good fruit too

55.description: I went on a weekend. And I live to tell the tale.Really, Andy's isn't that awful if you cannot speak Polish. I don't, and I made it out with my pride intact. But then again, I didn't join the masses at the counter jockeying for a sausage. I'm not an aficionado when it comes to Polish groceries. I wasn't raised eating the various pickles and fish and jams - but I do enjoy checking them out when I go shopping. I did find some inexpensive organic Kasha (buckwheat groats to you) and the "Old World Recipe" butter - Polish recipe, Chicago-produced. There's an amazing array of perogis there - no MSG was listed as an ingredient on the ones I purchased, and they were very tasty and small. The breads are interesting, but many of them come from a bakery a mere mile down the street - best to go there are get your loaves fresh from the source.I'll be back when I'm in the neighborhood.

9.description: I don't know what shop you whiners are going to but I'm 100% NOT Polish and I love this place.  We stop here on the way out of town, always park on the street in front and have a ball at this place.  My wife is part Polish but speaks not a speck of the lingo and we never have a problem here.  The meat counter has all this GREAT stuff you don't see where I come from.  We load up on sausages for the father in law. He appreciates the great quality while we like the great prices.   We have no idea what any of the labels mean but it's some kind of adventure just going.  Yes, they speak Polish, it's a POLISH DELI you nitwits!!!!!  I can't believe you clowns have an issue with it.  This is a MUST stop when we are anywhere close to this area of the city.

26.description: If you're looking for fresh meat or great sausage look no farther. Great place great selection and very nice people working there...

25.description: We found a place in the WISCONSON DELLS called "International Market" next to the Cracker Barrel across from the Outlet Mall (it is also a gas station)...ALL THEY SELL IS ANDY'S DELI MEATS AND PRODUCTS FROM THE STORE IN CHICAGO .  Great treats to have from the city!!!   The employees are all polish but speak english and are friendly!!   Fresh fresh fresh!!!

12.description: I love this place.  It's just 5 minutes from our house so we go here at least a couple times a month.  They have a great selection of meats, delicious cakes and other packaged goods.  We even ordered deli platters from Andy's for our wedding reception and they were a hit.  It's one of my favorite things about this neighborhood.  No need to speak polish just grab your number and get in line!

59.description: Went here ONE time and it was ONE time too many...Parking was a nightmare and even on the street in front of the place was hell!I bought a few things cause I figured with all the time I wasted trying to park, I might as well get something... I couldn't even get near the Deli too many smelly people around (  it was a HOT summer day )  and I had one of my little ones with me that I thought was going to get stepped on.  when I got to the check out, their machine was acting up and didn't like my debit card ( nothing was wrong with it )  so lucky for her, I had my check book handy..  word to the wise, IF you do not speak Polish don't go there period!and leave your kids at home, place is a ZOO on anyday of the week.

21.description: I live within walking distance from Andy's Deli and there's always a line in the parking lot... man this place is popular. I decided to check it out for the first time... but I should have read yelp reviews first. I am not trying to play the race card, but I really did not feel welcomed. All I wanted was smoked turkey, so I got in line. The people behind the counter made eye contact with me, but after 5 minutes of waiting, I was getting passed for the Polish speaking customers behind me... so I left. I heard that they now have a numbering system in place, so hopefully this works better for them.

17.description: Great prices, but really rude and intimidating staff. I have to take a Xanax to work up the nerve to go in there.

10.description: Bacon is hand crafted and $3.99 a lb. Sliced ham so good and European style you'll be making a special trip just to get that. Smoked meats, fresh pork & veal. The deli is immaculately clean. Prepared foods are available as well. You'd have to be crazy, or vegetarian not to like this place. For realzies

5.description: The best choice of all kinds of meat as far as sausage, ham and etc. I only shop here for all my deli. The store has plenty of imported goods that you can't get at other stores.Highly recommend it!

3.description: Great deli, However your deli counter help needs a lesson in the number system, it seem several times I have stood in a pretty long line with a ticket in my hand just to see someone walk up that one of the girls knows and start to take care of them, I was in there 2/8/15 when this occurred, not only was I skipped over and instead of the lady saying sorry Maam I will take you next, she was extremely rude in front of other customers yelling How I was going to have to wait my turn, having everyone turn and look down at me, I'm sorry but that one incident turned me off on patronizing your business...

35.description: Excellent Polish Deli.You will find here delicious pierogi, soups, meats and deserts. Polish chocolate, coffee, tea, bread, butter, and cheese. Maybe not necessarily in that order.  Ok anything polish you will find it at Andy's deli. Plus they lots of different polish beers and liquor. The servers speak English so no language problems and everyone is so nice. I recommend going during the week as the weekend gets very busy and it is a small store and a lot of Polish people do their weekend shopping here because it is very good. So if you are planing your first trip to Andy's go during the week..Also very very clean store and they always have fresh items.

19.description: Excellent Polish Deli.You will find here delicious pierogi, soups, meats and deserts. Polish chocolate, coffee, tea, bread, butter, and cheese. Maybe not necessarily in that order.  Ok anything polish you will find it at Andy's deli. Plus they lots of different polish beers and liquor. The servers speak English so no language problems and everyone is so nice. I recommend going during the week as the weekend gets very busy and it is a small store and a lot of Polish people do their weekend shopping here because it is very good. So if you are planing your first trip to Andy's go during the week..Also very very clean store and they always have fresh items.

28.description: we are German but, the food is very to close my mom's home cooking. I take her there and she loves the warm buffet style food as well as bakery goods. I love that too but, I also come for the deli. Everything is fresh and delicious! LOVE IT!!

45.description: Been here a couple of times...I have Polish ancestry, but only speak enough to figure out the names I'm researching genealogically.  haBut I never had a problem ordering or getting anything I wanted.  And no, they don't act all gushy like we are trained to do in the US, but it's a different culture.  Some of them probably feel like a fish out of water but, like any business with common sense, they want your patronage and moolah.I walked away from here with a wealth of bodacious offerings.  And I've actually "called in" orders with friends visiting Chicago without me.Do check it out.  It's an experience.  Chicago has the second-largest Polish population after Krakow and this is a place to immerse yourself in it.  Try something new and enjoy!

33.description: Folks, this is a Polish deli, are you surprised that all the food is Polish and the ladies here speak Polish, seriously?  Are you that easily intimidated?I love this place.  The quality of meats and selections is phenomenal!  I like that most of their deli meats are made by them, and not purchased from some warehouse.  They are juicy, super fresh and are seasoned just right (no blandness here!).  Yes, the lines are long, and I'd recommend against going on a Saturday cause it does get crazy, but that just proves, people will go through the craziness for the awesome food.  Take a number and learn the virtue of patience. Yes, the ladies at the counter mostly speak Polish, however most understand enough English to service you well.  If you stand there trying to "make eye contact" and hope that will get them to serve you, then wake up and take a number like everyone else.  Last time I was there, I saw some American older lady decked out in Louis Vuitton and she was so ticked she stood there for 15 min and no one helped her.  Hey sunshine, take a freaking number, your purse will not get you ahead of the line!  And she's probably the one to run and complain on yelp, ehhh people.The ready made dinner section opposite the deli is seriously super!  Its real polish cooking, I love that they use spices and dont make the selections boring or bland as some other Polish Deli's do.  Don't miss out on their soups, there is one which is like chicken soup (rosol z koldunami) with mini meat pierogi inside.  Love it!Park a block or two away and walk, its not the end of the world if you have to walk more than 10 steps to your car, you will survive, and be greatful for the delliciousness!  (I cracked up at the guys review who was traumatized by the parking situation and that for a few seconds he "blocked a lane")

43.description: I really am a fan of Polish deli's and this is one of the cleanest and best! The hot food counter has fresh selections all the time. I particularly enjoy the chicken meatballs and baked salmon with zucchini and peppers. They also have the mini pierogi (Uzaka) with mushrooms and these I love - they are so very scrumptious!

2.description: Grocery store/ hot and cold food deli.This is the real-polish-deal.I had a stuffed pepper and potato pancake for lunch. Makes you feel like you are in a polish grocery store that is actually in Poland.Not expensive, there is also a coffee bar and area to sit and eat your food.

18.description: I am half Polish but non-Polish speaking and live a block away. I don't go here unless I have a craving for stuffed cabbage or homemade chicken noodle soup. Never really had an issue asking staff for assistance and though they're not overly friendly, they are certainly not rude by any means. It's hysterical that there is a drop-box outside the exit labeled "Customer Complaints" situated directly beneath a security camera.

41.description: They are closed due to a fire. Thankfully no one was injured.  Reading the news reports it sounded pretty extensive. Not sure when they will re-open.

52.description: If you are looking for a grocery store where "everyone speaks 'merican", don't go here.However, if you enjoy European grocery stores or would like to try out that experience, Andy's is the place for you.  I always feel slightly like an outsider spying on a fascinating world I will never be a part of yet can experience through visiting while I am here.  I love perusing the aisles of imported juices, candies and jams, and checking out the uniquely Eastern European deli salads (mainly pickled) and bakery goods (like Napoleons).  I ordered cheese from the deli and they called someone over who spoke English to take care of me, though I wouldn't have minded fumbling through the order.Insider tip: The fresh produce is very inexpensive and fantastic quality.  Don't expect to find out of season items, though.  Poor boy buns and other fresh bakery breads are also great.  This place also does a wonderful fresh butcher business.  Check out the frozen cases for their homemade pierogis.Regarding Parking: There are two lots + street parking.  The second lot is south of the store and thus easier to find if you are approaching from the north.Bus: Milwaukee

50.description: the best polish deli I've ever been to, and I've been to a lot of those ....

4.description: The best Polish Deli/Supermarket in Chicago! They have many Polish dishes which you can buy from their hot bar and eat there. Or take home some soup, stuffed cabbage and pierogi's to eat later. The deli offers many imported and in house made deli meats and sausage's. They are one of the only places you can buy freshly made blood sausage! Many devilishly delightful items and breads in their bakery leave you pressed to make the right choice. Prices are much below average of the large supermarkets! A must stop when you're in the area!

6.description: Great Polish market. Pros: Friendly staff, large variety of meats, dairy, fish, vegetables, sauces & delicious food. There's also a hot bar area you can dine at. They take credit cards and you get a lot of bang for your buck. Cons: Closes early compared to other food markets, limited alcohol selection, only three cash registers, limited amount of staff to assist you look for items you want.

22.description: Andy's Deli in Niles has improved somewhat since our last visit in November '12, but trust me, it has a way to go! As a Polish born American, I'm very disappointed at Andy's Delis' representation of my culture...I wonder if Andy ever stepped foot on Poland's soil?! Yes, the pricing is very good, but the service is reminiscent of the old socialistic culture much in need of training and reform to accommodate our American culture, which was bulit on serving the customer!If you have a need to be disrespected, Andy's Deli does that well. If you expect good customer service, as we Americans do, there are other businesses that do a better job!

15.description: So agree with others- very unfriendly atmosphere. I think the counter help must just know if a customer is Polish. Though I have been in there numerous times, I have been treated rudely without regard. Counter help doesn't greet you - doesn't look at you, doesn't acknowledge what you say, when you tell them what you want - and they NEVER smile. Just blank, almost angry attitudes. I don't speak Polish - but come on! Andy's food is good, so I'm compelled to give 3 stars BUT they really lose because of their lack of customer service, which is a disgrace. They should be embarassed and really reconsider how they treat their customers.They obviously don't realize they represent a huge portion of Chicago's population, or maybe they would do better. Where is their Polish pride? I probably won't go back.

57.description: The moment I pulled up to the place it felt like an unwelcome visit. The store employs a fat guy with an orange vest and a cigarette in his mouth for parking lot traffic control. He stopped a car ahead of me and had it stay in the entrance of the lot until a space appeared. You see, their lot is so tiny that it is hard for cars to get in and out. Meanwhile, I was blocking the right lane on Milwaukee. So I went on and parked a block away and walked. By the time I got to the store, the fat guy already had 4 cars snared, including the one that was ahead of me. Now all of them were blocking the sidewalk and the right lane of Milwaukee. A moustached Polish guy stepped out of his car to see why he was not allowed into the lot. This was only about 3:15 PM. I can only imagine what a weekend must be like.I dashed between the tangle of cars and walked inside the store. Lots of crowded aisles. I got a basket since I thought carts would be too tight to navigate. I saw a nice round loaf of Polish multigrain bread for... $5.25? Is this a Polish Whole Foods? I know I can get a loaf like that for $2.50 or less elsewhere.OK, maybe I'll try the deli and get some sausage, ham or kiszka. No luck. The line is huge and I'm not sure who's turn it is or where to stand even. They didn't have much in terms of packaged deli items to grab and go, so waiting appeared to be the only option. As I walked down the narrow aisle near the refrigerated section, a short and skinny young Polish woman nearly disarmed me of my handbasket then gave me a dirty look as I tucked in the basket and turned the corner.And to top it off, the checkout lady saw me and assessed that I didn't look Polish enough (though I can speak it). In her broken English with a snobby voice she said, "Two seventy-eight." All I got were a Polish daily newspaper and a bag of corn puff snacks for the kids at home. Glad I didn't bring them here. I paid and dashed out. As I left, the Parking Nazi was directing a car to turn out and back into Milwaukee so it can make some room for another car getting out.Getting out is the right idea. I won't be coming back here.

20.description: Authentic, packed with pretty much everything Polish you could want, but definitely poorly organized at the checkout line. Even without worrying about parking, the checkout was enough to make us not buy anything. Not super helpful or friendly, as above mentioned.

36.description: I've driven past this place a million times but never stopped in until yesterday.  Now I am kicking myself in the ass for never trying it... Wow!This place is not a store to do your weekly shopping as there isn't much produce or dairy.  But the meat, deli, and prepared foods are unbelievable.  They have a computer generated number system that calls out your number like at the drivers license place.  It's crazy and hectic and the people are pushy, but they are really efficient.  There's also tables and chairs where you can sit down to eat your food.  We got a ton of different items just to sample the food and everything was outstanding.  There is so much to choose from and I wasn't sure what many things were. Some of it was obvious like the roast pork in gravy, pierogies, mashed potatoes, etc, but  the young girls working the hot counter speak English and happily explained what everything was.  Lots of pork and chicken, and everything was covered in bacon... ummm... bacon...Prices were awesome too, especially for good quality homemade food.  We spent $30 and had enough food for 5 people to eat, plus got a loaf of bread, some beer, paczkis, and a salami.  The place is FAST moving with people in and out quickly... no dawdling here.  Expect to be shoved out of the way many times.   :-)The next time you are craving some hot comfort food, this is the place to get it.

14.description: Visited this deli which to me seems like a small grocery store with a butcher shop to purchase some cheese and kelbasi to put in my luggage and take home. Upon arriving the selection in the butcher shop area was found to be fantastic as was the selection of  bakery items. Having limited room in my luggage and being unable to take anything that would spoil on a two hour fight I had to control myself. The staff was all speaking Polish but had no problems speaking English when I ordered. I purchased Weselna Kielbasa, Sur Studencki and some Tylzyki cheese. The Ser Studencki cheese was purchased on a recommendation of the nice lady behind the counter, not knowing what it tasted like she provided a sample to ensure I liked it, it's similar to Swiss. I also purchased fresh Danish for breakfast and they have a large selection of Polish chocolates and candies. I was so surprised at the very low prices of almost everything. This is a fantastic deli/grocery store with super friendly staff, I wish I could take the entire store home with me. I can guarantee the next time I'm in Chicago I'll be back. A designated parking lot is available while visiting the deli.

29.description: Place is clean but food is not that impressive. The tapsilog is just a few pieces and the eggs are small. The longganisa is not well cooked and has a taste.

42.description: This filipino food was ON POINT.  As a non-filipino, here's my short list of the must eats from Kawayan, which is the best filipino food I've tried in the city. Breakfast: Tocino with eggs over easy.  Appetizers.  Lumpia Shanghai and Sisig.Entrees: Kare Kare, Chicken Inasal, Pork Adobo, Bistec and Lechon.

23.description: I was kinda banning this place after being rejected the first time I went there during their opening week due to running out of food....but finally gave them a chance and am impressed with the food. Service is a tad slow but food is freshly cooked so its worth being patient for. I've yet to try everything on the menu but the last 2 times I've been there, the food was consistently delicious and comforting the way Filipino food should be. Parking is free but that lot gets packed with crazy drivers so be careful during peak hours

8.description: Dined in today after getting off the Blue Line on my way to relax at King Spa. All Filipino patrons in an unassuming strip mall location next to Jefferson Park transit center. Ordered lumpia shanghai and one piece of inasal. Lumpia were crispy and tasty - a deep fried guilty pleasure. The chicken was moist and juicy on the inside but char-crispy on the outside. The dipping sauce seemed to be made with lemongrass, coconut, vinegar and soy sauce - super delish. Served with white rice, it was a LOT of food for under $15.There will definitely be leftovers tomorrow - way better deal than the cafe at the spa. The people who own and run the restaurant were very sweet and appropriately attentive (not invasive). The service bumped my rating up from four to five stars. I will have to try kare kare next time!

31.description: My wife and I have been here three times in the past month, and will probably be back again this weekend because we love it so much. Beef caldereta - so tender it practically melts in your mouth. Geez, it feels like I am eating it right now. Sinigang - they use real tamarind and not just powdered packet so it gives the authentic flavor to it that I grew up on. Actually it might be a little better than the stuff I grew up on. (Don't tell my mom)Bistec Tagalog - again, very tender and again very good. Pork Belly Sisig - ok, this is NOT the sisig that you are used to eating. It isn't the crispy lean sisig that you might expect. It isn't as lean, and it's cooked in a white sauce that tastes real good. In all honesty, I think mayonnaise is involved with it, but trust me it is good. Pancit - Any good Filipino restaurant HAS to have good pancit...and yes Kawayan does as well! I could've easily taken down the entire plate by myself, but we also had the sisig that day...I didn't want to fill up on my month's worth of calories in just one meal. Service is great, very friendly...if you see the owner Chris, he is very engaging and helpful. One of my favorite non-food things about this restaurant is the open kitchen. It reminds me of big Filipino parties at my mom's or relatives' house seeing all the cooks in the kitchen. As I said we'll be back again possibly tomorrow...so yes, we do like it there.

34.description: The service was great, but the good wasn't that great. This was the first time I had Filipino food, so I don't know if I just didn't like it or if the food was bad... I just found it very bland and flavorless.

16.description: My wife and I have been here three times in the past month, and will probably be back again this weekend because we love it so much. Beef caldereta - so tender it practically melts in your mouth. Geez, it feels like I am eating it right now. Sinigang - they use real tamarind and not just powdered packet so it gives the authentic flavor to it that I grew up on. Actually it might be a little better than the stuff I grew up on. (Don't tell my mom)Bistec Tagalog - again, very tender and again very good. Pork Belly Sisig - ok, this is NOT the sisig that you are used to eating. It isn't the crispy lean sisig that you might expect. It isn't as lean, and it's cooked in a white sauce that tastes real good. In all honesty, I think mayonnaise is involved with it, but trust me it is good. Pancit - Any good Filipino restaurant HAS to have good pancit...and yes Kawayan does as well! I could've easily taken down the entire plate by myself, but we also had the sisig that day...I didn't want to fill up on my month's worth of calories in just one meal. Service is great, very friendly...if you see the owner Chris, he is very engaging and helpful. One of my favorite non-food things about this restaurant is the open kitchen. It reminds me of big Filipino parties at my mom's or relatives' house seeing all the cooks in the kitchen. As I said we'll be back again possibly tomorrow...so yes, we do like it there.

13.description: The food is really good. We ordered crispy pata, daing na bangus and kare-kare.  Thr price is comparable to other Filipino restaurants. We went during our lunch hour so not much people eating. Im sure it could have a little wait time during dinner because the place is really small. Their tables are really small too so for the table for 4 and the food we ordered, it could barely fit.  I would recommend this restaurant if you're in Chicago area. Easy access to public transportation too. - cta blue line

11.description: Accidentally came across this place. Just ordered the Kare-Kare. Delicious!  The meet was tender and good sauce. Not too thin/watery. What I found most interesting is that the portion of meet to vegetables was perfect. Most places that I've been to has more vegetables than beef. Which is annoying because who wants to eat an eggplant Kare Kare? Will definitely be back to try more dishes.  Also very friendly staff!

39.description: First off Im a germaphobe when I eat out. Secondly, Im very critical of Filipino food I eat (my family are great cooks). On that note here are my thoughts of this place;1) Open Kitchen - very clean and I love to see what goes behind the scenes2) Different Cooking Styles -  like Chinese and Italians , Filipinos have diff cooking styles depending on what region your family may be from. So the way they make Sisig or even Bistec Tagalog or even the Classic Adobo may be different then what you are used to or even what you are expecting. So definitely ASK how its prepared and what ingredients are in it. 3) If you are new to Filipino Food or you are bringing someone who is,  I would start them off with something very safe like the eggrolls you can't go wrong and that will make a smooth intro to Filipino fare.

37.description: This is some great home-cooked comfort food. I'm not an expert on Filipino food, but I do love meat and noodles and rice. We came with a group of 16 after making reservations (recommended as the whole place seats about 30 or so. The staff was extremely accommodating and willing to move chairs and tables around. You could tell that they wanted to make us feel at home. The food was on point. We left it to our waitress to pick out whatever she thought would satisfy us. She pretty much left no stone unturned as we were presented with different varieties of noodles, rice, pork, beef, chicken and seafood dishes. For appetizers, they brought out probably 100 lumpia and a bbq pork sisig (skewer) for everyone. These were the best lumpia I've had in the city. I'd pick these over any "stuff wrapped in something then fried". We had the pancit noodles and adobo rice. I highly recommend both. They brought out a lot of entrees but the ones that stood out were the lechon, crispy pata, pork and chicken adobo, and dinuguan. Yes. There is a lot of meat on the menu. It kind of hard to avoid. We did have one vegetarian in the group, and they did their best to accomodate. At the end they brought out some flan and coconut desserts for us to share...on the house. It was a great experience. It ended up being about $20 per person including tip with a good amount of leftovers to take home. And it's BYOB. I'll definitely be back probably with a smaller group and try some of the other dishes. And I heard breakfast is a must.

0.description: Overall, this was a good, casual spot for Filipino comfort food.I had the Chicken Inasal, which is a bit hard to find at most Philippine restaurants.  They did a good job with their version of this Bacolod region dish.  It was tasty and tender and seasoned well.  For dessert I had the Buko Pandan - this was great...very rich and decadent...a little on the sweet side, but I really enjoyed it.If I'm in the area, I'd definitely come back here...a short walk from the Jefferson Park CTA stop!

38.description: My son ate here twice in a week and brought me back for a third trip, I loved it! Had the beefstec! Delicious! I am also a big fan of their halo halo! The staff was great the place was spotless! I will definitely be back!

27.description: Foods great! They just need more than one cook.. Or at least the employees around him should help out. They're just standing there. And to top it off, they left early for the day. Smh

32.description: Tapsilog was terrible. Costs $8.00. The meat they used was the beef used in making nilaga. There was no hint of garlic, soy sauce and kalamansi at all. Ruby's tapsilog is way better!The tocilog was pink. No taste as well. Please see picture.

44.description: Tried Kawayan on day 2 of their soft opening and YUM!   Menu offers a lot of favorite traditional dishes and authentic dishes I had never heard of like the chicken inasal.  Our orders came out hot, fresh and delish!  The chicken inasal was marinated and grilled perfectly and the coconut-curry-lemongrass sauce was the perfect complement.   Crispy Pata was moist, tender and crispy and was bigger than we expected for the price.   Lumpia shanghai was also perfect...rolled tight and with the right amount of filling.     Flan was also delish and not too sweet.  Breakfast is served everyday and overall the prices are reasonable for the portions served.   Will definitely return and recommend to friends and fam.

24.description: Found Kawayan using my good old buddy yelp lol. SOOOO good!!! How do you say meat coma in Tagalog?! Everything was so good! The adobo, palabok, OMG GET THE LECHE FLAN, that is an ORDER!!! Officially in the top 2 of the best leche flans I've uever had!!They do lose a star though because while the kare kare had a good sauce and veggies, there were only chunks of tough beef. No oxtail or tripe!! *boooo*Still going though!! I need to try their filipino breakfast, I have yet to find a good spot out here for it!

7.description: Crispy pata is superb, kare- kare was so tasty, and the seafood bicol express was awesome! Difinitely we are going to be back and dine in ir maybe just call for pick up orders. And the costumer service is also 5 stars.

40.description: It was my first time here and The dish was excellent. I had a porkcilog with garlic rice so delicious especially the garlic rice plus I had a beefsteak they cooked so good. And what I like it the most is they're very friendly people. Now I found my closest spot for my comfort food;)

30.description: I went here with my parents for Sunday lunch.  We arrived around 12:30 and there was no wait which was great since the place holds only about 30 people.  12 eggrolls ("Lumpia Shanghai") for less than $6 - Awesome!  And they tasted great, too!  My parents ordered the Kare-Kare & I ordered the Chicken Adobo. I ended up eating more of their meal because the peanut sauce was so good.  They suggested I eat the beef with the bangaong that was served on the side but I guess I'm just too American because it tasted better without it.  My chicken adobo was just ok.  I think it's because this dish was my grandpa's specialty and I'll never find anyone that could cook it better.  For dessert we shared a Halo-Halo.  I'm not a fan of this popular Filipino dessert but my parents love it.  I just ate some of the ice cream on top of it. I didn't give this place 5 stars because it took a while for us to get our food and water refilled.   Maybe it was because another table of 10 ordered a bunch of dishes ahead of us OR because it was just one waiter serving everyone.  I'd go back here if I ever feel the need for Filipino food and my mom doesn't feel like cooking.

46.description: The previous owners of the closed Filipiniana have opened up a new spot to serve that delicious food that they once served. Conveniently located  across the way from the Jefferson Park in Veterans Plaza, makes getting there a breeze. There is a free parking lot, and of course, bus and train accessible. It's a cozy place that can fit about 50-75 people (depending on the seating arrangement) with very friendly staff. We arrived right when they opened and the place was bustling already with people of all races enjoying their food. Luckily, we were seated right away and I decided to "take it all in". The waiter, Jerry, who was very helpful and knowledgeable assisted us to help make some decisions on what food choices to for our party soon to be arriving any moment. For starters we ordered the Bbq pork skewers and the Lumpia Shanghai.  BBQ pork cooked to perfection on a stick served with a garlic vinegar dipping sauce. We devoured it, it stood no chance. Lumpia Shanghai was fried golden and served with a sweet chili dipping sauce. I must say that I was already impressed with the service upon entrance but the appetizers made us excited about the rest of the meal we were about to have. For the rest of the meal I need to break it down because it deserves some detailed reviewing:-Insal na Chicken (bbq chicken) - Chicken can be messed up so easily but Kawayan did it just right. Thank the Lord! Juicy bbqed chicken served with a sweet sauce. -Bistec Taglog - Sliced and marinated beef. Cooked with a soy sauce, garlic and calamansi (small limes- but more flavorful). Cooked with sliced onions. It reminded me of my grandmother's! It really took me back and the flavors melded so well together. It married perfectly over white rice (which it is served with). -Crispy Pata - Deep fried pork knuckle served with vinegar or "mang tomas" which is a sweet dipping sauce. I would say it reminds me of a meaty chicharron flavor. It's a huge serving and I suggest you get it when you have 3 or more people to help you tackle this delicious dish.-Kare Kare - If you don't know, you must. I am totally serious. It's a Philippine stew flavored with peanut butter, they serve it with fork tender beef, boy choy, green beans, and eggplant. I know it sounds weird but I promise you, it is outrageously delicious. Kare kare can easily be messed up if you make it more like a soupy consistency and I am glad they made sure that the stew was thick and super flavorful. That stew had such developed flavors it was wonderful. Put that over some rice and that in itself is a meal. Just thinking of this again is making my mouth water.-Daing na Bangus - De-boned milkfish marinated with fresh garlic, salt, pepper, vinegar. Fried until golden brown and  delicious. I am not a fish eater. I don't know why, I am just not. This fish though, I make an exception for. It is that good. Really, try it, don't hesitate. It tastes like chicken but with all those flavors that it was marinated in locked in by that fry but not over cooked. The staff informed me that they serve Filipino breakfast dishes all day. Tocilog (sweet cured pork served over garlic fried rice and an egg on top), tapsilog(fried beef served over garlic fried rice and an egg on top), Longsilog (sweet cured pork sausage served over garlic fried rice and an egg), Bangsilog (deep fried milkfish served over garlic fried rice and an egg, etc. All these dishes come with a dipping sauce of some sort and if you know me, I am the accoutrement queen! I was in dipping sauce heaven. All perfect accompaniments to their meals and not over powering.Not only did I enjoy the food but I also enjoyed the wonderful service they gave my family. The owner's came out to mingle with the patrons of their establishment and took some time to talk to us about their history and small chit chat. I knew they were wildly busy but took the time out to anyway. That is grade-A service that I expect. They gave me the feeling of feeling welcomed in their home. I can see that they take a great sense of pride in their food and give it their all. I love when I see passion in a restaurateur's eyes.  I am positive that everything else on the menu is just as delicious, be adventurous and try something new because you just might like it, especially if it comes from Kawayan. One of the owner's told me that they will be holding special events in the near future - all which sound delicious!In all, we enjoyed our meal and we will be back time and time again. A great time and meal was had by all. I would like to apologize for not snapping a photo of everything we got since we devoured it so quickly. I captured what I could. See you soon Kawayan!

1.description: The food is DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!  I have had a craving for Filipino food...and I decided to google a Filipino resturarant near me...well Kawayan came up!  I ordered Bihon/Canton Combo, Lumpia Shanghai and Kakanin...it is the BEST food I have enjoyed lately.  Great size portions and well worth my $!!!!!  I would recommend this place over and over again!!!!!Thank you Kawayan!

9.description: Work close to this place. A Filipino friend recommended it. I have made the habit of making a meal out of lumpia! I can't complain about this place.

26.description: I have to say that Kawayan is probably one of the most authentic Filipino restaurants in Chicagoland. They have the best SINIGANG. They cook sinigang with real tamarind instead of tamarind mix. Their Kare-kare is at par. It is everything that I want in Kare-kare - tender meat, right consistency of the soup and most especially, the taste! It makes me feel like I was dining in the Philippines. I would say that their pricing is reasonable. The ambiance is more pleasant than most Filipino restaurants in the city. The staff is nice and friendly. They try to remember customers by name which is great.   I recommend it to everyone!

25.description: We've been here a few times. Okay, okay...I love that it's around the neighborhood! HOORAY! I love ordering their Longsilog (Longanisa, fried rice, and sunny side up egg, with a side of vinegar). My husband tried the sisig a couple of times, and hence we just keep coming back. I love the location and I love the fact that if I'm feeling for the Filipino food; It hits the spot!

12.description: I really enjoyed this place and thanks to a Yelp review hit a home run in the ordering.  The service was also great, they really cared about pleasing us and were proud of their food.  We started with two appetizers.  First was the Lumpia Shanghai, which was a huge portion (maybe 10) Filipino springrolls and a good dipping sauce.  I love spring rolls and these were great, crispy and the dipping sauce was good (and there were a lot).  Also had the pork skewers, which were tasty with a lot of good pork.The entrees were also good.  We had the Kare Kare, which is sort of like a pot roast in a peanut sauce (probably totally butchering what it is but just try it).  It was really good and a very hefty portion. Our other entree was the crispy pata.  I really loved this and am dying to go back for it.  It was a full pork knuckle or shank, a huge piece of meat.  The pork is very tender and the skin is crisp, just like pork rinds if you have had them.Both portions were tremendous so no room for dessert but anxious to go back.

21.description: Food is very good. We enjoyed Lumpia Shanghai for appetizer. Had Pork Sinigang soup, Chicken Inasal & Lechon Kawali for the main course. Yes, too much food for just 2 people but it was all so good. I even ordered Leche Flan to go! Service was great too. Even my very white boyfriend was blown away with everything. Will definitely go back there soon.

17.description: Tapsilog was terrible. Costs $8.00. The meat they used was the beef used in making nilaga. There was no hint of garlic, soy sauce and kalamansi at all. Ruby's tapsilog is way better!The tocilog was pink. No taste as well. Please see picture.

Conveniently located  across the way from the Jefferson Park in Veterans Plaza, makes getting there a breeze. There is a free parking lot, and of course, bus and train accessible.
